text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
Made minor editorial changes throughout to correct spelling and punctuation errors and citations.

Updated IRM 8.10.2.1.6 (3) to change the operating division title from LMSB to LB&I. The procedure now states that a copy of any report containing specific examples of tax abuses in the international area should be furnished to the Large Business & International (LB&I) Director, International Business Compliance (IBC) or International Individual Compliance (IIC),

Updated IRM 8.10.2.1.2.2 to clarify the procedures for Appeals Technical Employees when making a referral or reporting to the Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) to reflect the Small Business Work Opportunity Tax Act of 2007 (SBWOTA) law that was enacted on May 25, 2007.

Clarified IRM 8.10.2.1.2.3, Referrals to Compliance, to reference registered tax return preparers as well as unenrolled preparers. Added IRM 8.10.2.1.2.3 (2) to provide a link to an internal use list maintained on the Return Preparer Office website of active enrolled agents and registered tax return preparers that can be viewed to confirm credentials.

) Information pertaining to possible disclosures to be made under IRC will be reported by memorandum, through channels, to the responsible sure Manager. The memorandum should contain the following information: a. Name, social security number, address, and aliases of subject (if b. Business or occupation of subject (if known), c. Facts and circumstances surrounding the nontax violation, d. U.S. Code sections believed violated, e. Specific source of information, i.e.,

rd party, and the circumstances which the information was obtained, f. Agency to whom this violation would be of interest, e.g., U.S. Attorney (Judicial District), Strike Force Attorney (location), or other agency (specify), g. Privacy Act system of records from which information was obtained, h. A statement as to whether or not disclosure would identify a confidential informant or seriously impair a civil or criminal tax investigation. (

) Bribe offers are often subtle and indirect. When bribe overtures are by employees, they must promptly report them so that trained personnel evaluate and initiate an investigation. Any Appeals employee who believes a bribe attempt has been made must: a. avoid any implication of acceptance or rejection but hold matter in abeyance; b. report the attempt immediately to Treasury Inspector General for Tax ministration (TIGTA); Internal Revenue Manual

) No report to the Office of Professional Responsibility will be made on any referred to TIGTA. When appropriate, TIGTA will advise the Office of Profes- sional Responsibility of the complaint against the practitioner. (

) The Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) exercises jurisdiction over tax professionals who interact with the tax administration system. This to the Office of Attorneys, CPAs, Enrolled Agents, Enrolled Actuaries and Registered Tax Return Preparers. OPR also exercises jurisdiction over any individual who compensation prepares, or assists in the preparation of, all or a substantial portion of a document pertaining to any taxpayer’s tax liability for the Internal Revenue Service. a. , “Regulations Governing Practice before the Internal Revenue Service.″ An isolated instance in which penalty may apply should not, in and of itself, require a referral unless conduct is involved. Accordingly, the imposition of penalties under IRC and IRC

) Registered tax return preparers or unenrolled preparers of returns are not permitted to represent taxpayers before Appeals. (cid:

authorizes registered return preparers represent taxpayers only before revenue agents or similar IRS and only in connection with an examination of the taxable year or period covered by a return prepared and signed by the registered return (
) Conduct of a return preparer that would render the preparer ineligible to appear as the taxpayer’s representative should be reported to the Return Preparer Coordinator using Form
, Appeals Division Feedback Report and Transmittal Memorandum. (

) The Return Preparer Office maintains a list of active enrolled agents and tered tax return preparers. These lists are updated monthly and for internal purposes only. You can view the lists on the Return Preparer Office website. You can use the lists to confirm individuals’ credentials, including in to external inquiries, but you should not provide them in their entirety to any external sources. (

) Information about racketeers who infiltrate legitimate businesses should be reported by memorandum to the appropriate Special Agent in Charge, Investigation Division. Such action is not precluded by the fact that the mate income has been correctly reported. (

) The memorandum should include to the extent known: a. name, address and social security number (SSN) of the racketeer; b. name, address, and employee identification number (EIN) of the and description of the business activities; c. all known or suspected aliases, nominees, and close business d. nature and extent of the investment in and control of business; e. if the information relates to extensive or questionable use of a financial institution’s services, the nature and extent thereof; and f. all other pertinent data including source of information and how Internal Revenue Manual

Appeals Reports and (

) To wage a more effective fight against organized crime, the Federal ment initiated a program designed to strike a blow at key members of the Liaison in underworld. The Criminal Investigation Division and Department of Justice coordinating a program in which Federal agencies concentrate enforcement Cases efforts on designated organized crime subjects in selected cities. Each is called a “Strike Force.” The Service participates in each Strike Force by ignating one or more persons to represent the Internal Revenue Service. (

) Normal procedures governing review and processing of organized crime are applicable to tax cases resulting from the strike force program. For protested to Appeals, the case file will be identified or marked so as to a Strike Force connection and processing of the case will be expedited. Appeals Office having jurisdiction will establish liaison with IRS Strike Force representatives to keep informed of new developments and to inform the Force of the progress and status of the case. (

) The Internal Revenue Service submits tax legislative recommendations and proposed tax regulations to the Treasury Department. Every officer and and employee whose work affords an opportunity to recognize needed changes should be alert for opportunities to make recommendations to this program. Appeals employees in the field are especially in a position to observe, evaluate, and submit solutions to tax administration and compliance such as improvement in taxpayer relations, simplification, tax avoidance schemes and efforts to counter them, tax loopholes, abuses and inequities. (

) Recommendations involving changes in tax legislation and tax regulations should not be processed through the Incentive Awards Program but through the Technical Coordination Program described below. (
) Such recommendations may, after enactment or adoption, be presented for award consideration and recognition, using Form
However, awards not be paid in advance of enactment of legislation or implementation of a suggested change in a regulation. (

) A Technical Coordination Report is submitted in memorandum form to tax abuses, inequities, or administrative problems in the interpretation and Coordination plication of the tax laws that are proper for consideration by Headquarters connection with the clarification of Service positions, amendment of regula- tions, or legislative recommendations. (

) The memorandum prepared by Appeals field personnel will be submitted through channels to the Area Director for evaluation and concurrence. referred by the Area Director to the Director Field Operations will typically include operational procedures in Appeals or settlement guidelines. The Director Field Operations will forward the memorandum to the Director, Tax Policy and Procedure and/or Director, Domestic Operations or Director, national Operations. (

) A copy of any report containing specific examples of tax abuses in the tional area should also be furnished to the Large Business & International (LB&I) Director, International Business Compliance (IBC) or International vidual Compliance (IIC). (
) Reports concerning any phase of Employee Plans or Exempt Organizations operations, whether pertaining to rulings, regulations, compliance, Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
N
8.10 Appeals Reports and
Reports concerning any phase of Employee Plans or Exempt Organizations operations, whether pertaining to rulings, regulations, compliance, collection,
legislation, forms, etc. should be directed to the TEGE Operating Division, Director, Employee Plans or Director, Exempt Organizations. (

) Reports (not concerning EP/EO matters) that involve tax forms or or taxpayer and other technical publications, should be directed to the W&I, Director Media and Publications, Tax Forms and Publications Division. (
) Reports (not concerning EP/EO matters) that suggest, or recommend of, revenue rulings, revenue procedures or the Code or regulations should directed to the Deputy Chief Counsel (Technical). (

) Technical Coordination Reports marked “COMMISSIONER’S ATTENTION” should be submitted where significant tax abuses, inequities and problems are noted, and one or more of the following characteristics are present: a. A large number of taxpayers are affected. b. A large amount of revenue or potential revenue is involved. c. The matter relates to a key policy of the President, the Secretary of the Treasury, or Congress. d. The matter is causing or may cause a significant amount of adverse publicity or public controversy. e. The matter is creating significant problems in the audit of returns, or litigation. (

) These reports are submitted on a memorandum explaining why the matter selected for the Commissioner’s attention. The memorandum is sent channels to the Area Director, who upon concurrence, forwards a copy of report to the Chief Appeals as well as the Director, Tax Policy and and/or Director, Domestic Operations or Director, International Operations.
